Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2007 06:05AM vickycnj wrote: thanks for the support. it is difficult learning a new "foreign language" over night but that is what i feel i have to do...."dcis; in situ; re-excision" etc.etc.  i read the public info posted here and many of the terms and shorthand jargon confuse me. i guess i will learn it as i travel here. the one thing i see familiar is that you as i are an lcsw by trade. i currently work in the schools. it is difficult as this is when the kids are getting back with all sorts of issues and i have been out for a week already and still have a drain hanging from my side at least through tuesday. the surgeon said social workers, nurses and doctors are always the most fearful patients- i guess i am fulfilling her notion!  is there a link that you can recommend to find out all the questions i should ask on tuesday when my path results come in. i know a few "what stage"; "how invasive" etc. but i want to be prepared. thanks again for your encouragement. occassionally i gasp but am trying to breathe again .

Posts.Content: vickycnj wrote: hi i am frightened; i am in denial; i hurt. i am trying to stay calm as i know it helps healing. i am trying to stay strong for my family and friends. i have no patience for being a patient. i have always been the caregiver. it hurts that others are trying to care for me. it hurts that some are avoiding me. since 17 i have had cystic breasts. at 34 i developed ovarian cysts that ruptured. a onocologic gyn put me on low dose pills to stop the cysts. i have no family hx. of breast cancer. i do not smoke.  i am an active, healthy woman who works and enjoys life. i have cancer. i have had mammograms yearly since i was 35. my first digital mammogram was in nov. 2006. it was clear. then in july 2007 my gyn didnt like the feel of a breast lump. sent me for a mammogram (the insurance would only pay for the right since i was 3 months shy of the annual). it showed calcificaltions. then they did an ultrasound (again only the right breast) which showed nothing. i begged my insurance co to do the left. my physician had to lie and say that they felt a lump so that it would be covered. luckily the tests showed nothing there.they indicated a 3mm calcification area of concern in the right breast. my gyn and internist pressed for a biopsy. i had a stereotactic on the right breast 2 1/2 weeks ago after begging them to move up a six week appt. the pathology showed in situ inductal carcinoma. the procedure was a little uncomfortable but the day after it felt like i was in a fight-sore and bruised.  i was told it was a hemotoma that formed. i was then scheduled for an mri.  it showed a 3mm mass. i was told i had to have it removed. i tried to get a breast surgeon in my insurance plan- bc/bs ppo but the first available appointment was a month later- so, i went back to my original dr from when i was 17. she is known in the state and heads up a breast center but accepts no insurance, so it is a pay as you go and submit to insurance plan. this will be my "vacation" for awhile. she scheduled a wide incision surgery. now i have asked her on at least 3 occassions and still dont know- was that a lumpectomy? she says she doent like that term.i had the wire location prior to surgery (it felt fine in the first 3 min. then kind of uncomfortable for the next 5 min. then okay agan till the end- but nothing horrible). then 1 1/2 hrs later i had surgery under "twilight" and local- (i felt nothing and would recommend). but...no one told me that when i woke i would have a drain bag for at least a week; be swaddled like winnie the pooh; not be able to bathe/shower for a week; have to await results for over a week from pathology. they told me i would not be able to do anything the next day... wow what a different scenario.  i was told that they took the size of "an egg" from my breast. when i asked if the procedure removed the initial lump or just the calcifications i was told that the site was removed as per the radiologists needle localizations. so- i didnt really get an answer. i have now had 5-6 days of recovery. still in a little pain. mostly achy and no energy. drain bag still in place. tuesday afternoon i go for pathology reports. y is this all so cryptic? i think the process needs to include the patient more- giving a heads up on all the scenarios so that they can understand what can/cant happen. im still not sure of whether i had a lumpectomy/ why there is this down time of over a week/ what the pathology report will show etc/etc. i am frightened; i feel stupid; i wish i knew more. knowledge brings comfort. so now i wait...tick/tick. tuesday p.m. i will hear of pathology and destiny. in the meanwhile i have seen how much a friend means; what a gift a family member is; how frightened and weird a boyfriend can be. my prayers and spirit are with all of you and me, --vicky Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2007 05:49AM vickycnj wrote: when i had the stereotactic biopsy i also had on site bleeding for about 2-3 days. the procedure was not painful compared to the achey feeling over the next week. when i had an mri the next week they said there was a hematoma(internal bleed) at this site and this was confirmed when they operated. they had given me a list of things not to eat /drink for 14 days  before the procedure to lessen bleeding and although i basically followed them i could not to the letter of the law (garlic!), the 1st time i went to see my surgeon i waited for over 2 1/2 hours. i just kept thinking that she must have been with someone that required more immediate attention to keep myself from flipping. the alternative was to wait weeks more to see another group of doctors. good luck with the reseults. my prayers are with you!
